Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 24: Subduing the Demon [Māra].
The demon Mara owned two victory standards, Banner of Desire and Banner of Doubt.

Manual - English: While sitting in equanimity under the Bodhi Tree (byang chub kyi shing), he is visited upon by seven messengers who are apparitions created by the demon. The scene of the Buddha taming the demon should be drawn as in the mainstream, hence there is no need to draw a throne.  In another scene, the Buddha sits in equanimity under a Bodhi Tree. The tree has big white branches with leaves held up by gods. According to the traditions of history (sngon 'byung) and Vinaya (‘dul ba), the only scene to be drawn here is three daughters of the demon trying to seduce the Buddha.

Sun of Faith - English: At that precise moment, Banner of Doubt began to quiver.
Mara, trying to find out why, saw that the Bodhisattva had that instant seated himself on the Diamond Throne.
Bent on overturning the Great Being’s plans, the demon disguised himself as a messenger with long bushy hair and a ragged loincloth round his waist and sprang out of a thicket, shouting:
“Devadatta (Lhas byin) has conquered Kapilavastu (Ser skya gzhi)! He has destroyed your palace! The Shakyas have given themselves up! How can you just sit there under that tree?”
The Bodhisattva knew that the demon’s ability to disrupt [his concentration] consisted in provoking three harmful reactions: desire, spite and violence.
He therefore suppressed these emotions by letting their three positive counterparts radiate in all their splendor.
Then Mara the Demon abandoning his disguise appeared in front of him, saying:
“What makes you so sure that you will attain perfect wisdom?”
The Bodhisattva replied: “Mara, you rule today over the desire realm world because of a single act of generosity on your part.
Over the course of three incalculable kalpas, I have performed hundreds, millions, billions of generous acts.
I have continually made offerings of all there is to offer—rare stones, precious metals, my hands and even my head—in order to serve beings.
It is absolutely impossible for me not to attain perfect wisdom.”
“You yourself have just borne witness to the fact that I did indeed perform this act,” replied Mara. “Where’s your witness, then?”
Siddhartha touched the ground with his right hand—the same bodhisattva’s hand that had accomplished such huge numbers of positive deeds, and declared: “The Earth is my witness!”
At that moment the Earth goddess, Prthividevi (Sa’i lha mo) emerged from its deepest depths and with her palms joined, attested: “The words of the Bhagavan are true.”

Sun of Faith - English: Scared, Mara fled.
He then summoned his daughters, Trsna (Sred ma, ‘Thirst’), Rati (Dga’ byed ma, ‘Pleasure’) and Raga (Dga’ spyod ma, ‘Enjoyment’) and gave them certain orders.
Manual - English: As in the Abhiniskramana and the Vinaya draw only three daughters of Mara displaying tempation. This is the section on the Taming of Mara.

Sun of Faith - English: But the demonesses, who belonged to the highest class of daughters of the gods (Devakanya), had hardly begun to weave their charms when the Blessed One’s [farsighted] benediction turned them into three old hags.
Inscription - English: Three yong women turned into old hags

Sun of Faith - English: Next, rallying together all the evil spirits of the House of Shadows, Mara—bristling all over with bows and arrows—made these, his troops, file past.
Inscription - English: While dwelling in Vajrāsana, (Buddha) tamed 36 million demons with compassion

Sun of Faith - English: Thirty-six million fierce demons, as misshapen of body as of mind, a nightmarish jumble of heads and limbs, fearless and pitiless, all paraded by brandishing weapons that were as cruel as they were grotesque.
These devilish legions encircled the Bodhisattva.
The Bodhisattva calmly remained in the meditation centered on loving-kindness:
the hail of weapons that the demons hurled at him turned into a soft rain of lotuses and bluish water lilies;
and when they pelted him with mountains, these converted into flower palaces.
The gods of the Pure Realm, (Gnas gtsang ma, Shuddhanivasa) stood in the way so as to block the deadly winds and the hail of stones.
Even the clouds of dust and drifts of stinking filth turned into a swirl of sweet offerings with an exquisite fragrance.
All the demonic attacks failed and so the demons left.
Knowing that noise is the worst enemy of someone trying to concentrate hard, Mara turned the Bodhi tree into a tree of crystal and whipped up a hurricane—thus raising an ear-splitting din.
The gods of the Pure Realm, by stilling one leaf each, restored the silence.
But the demons lingered; so the gods, fed up by this time, banished them to the other side of the world in order to get rid of them once and for all.
Even then one could hear their dreadful racket.
Afraid that the noise might adversely affect the Bodhisattva’s concentration, the gods surrounded him with a forest twelve leagues thick of kadam trees.
And all became serene.
